name: Klarna
title: AI Customer Service Experiment (and Correction)

classification.classificationRationale: Klarna did not create a named AI unit or CoE. CEO Siemiatkowski drove enterprise-wide AI adoption directly: AI replaced 700 customer service agents, workforce shrank 40% from 5,000 to ~3,000. No formal AI organizational structure described—this is CEO-mandate-driven adoption, characteristic of Model 6a. Contextual orientation: AI was adopted across existing workflows without creating new structural entities. Notable as a reversal case: after going full-tilt AI, Klarna resumed human hiring acknowledging quality degradation.

description:
Klarna's AI experiment provides a rare honest case study of both AI's potential and its limits. They publicly reversed course after going 'full tilt toward AI-based support.'
- February 2024: AI assistant announced as 'doing the equivalent work of 700 full-time agents' within first month
- Initial results: 2.3 million conversations, matching human satisfaction scores
- 25% drop in repeat inquiries, resolution time dropped from 11 minutes to under 2 minutes
- $40 million annual savings projected; workforce shrank 40% from 5,000 to ~3,000
- By 2025, Klarna reversed course, resuming human hiring after acknowledging 'a full tilt toward AI-based support roles resulted in lower quality work'
- New model: Hybrid approach with AI handling simple inquiries, humans handling nuance and complexity

observableMarkers.metrics: CEO Siemiatkowski: 'It is important that customers always have a clear path to a human.' Company now recruits remote support staff in 'Uber type of setup.'

mechanisms.name: Bonus Teams That Kill Projects
mechanisms.evidence: Klarna reversed course after going full-tilt AI, resuming human hiring. This is the rare demonstrated willingness to kill an AI initiative when quality suffered. CEO publicly acknowledged the correction. While not literally a bonus, the organizational courage to reverse a high-profile AI strategy demonstrates the kill-discipline this mechanism describes.

layers.label: Curation Review
layers.summary: Model 6a (Enterprise-Wide Adoption, Unnamed/Informal) with Contextual orientation validated. Klarna did not create a named AI unit—the CEO drove enterprise-wide AI adoption directly, replacing 700 agents with AI, then reversed course. This is the informal, top-down adoption pattern of Model 6a. Contextual orientation confirmed: no named AI structure, CEO-driven cultural mandate. Fixed industry from Technology to Fintech. Removed weak Mechanism #5 (the pattern here is not deploy-before-knowing; it is CEO-mandated rapid adoption followed by correction). Added habitat data. This specimen is valuable as a CAUTIONARY case—demonstrates limits of pure AI substitution.

contingencies.ceoTenure: Critical. AI strategy is entirely CEO-driven. Siemiatkowski's personal conviction drove both the AI push and the correction.

tensionPositions.structuralVsContextual: Contextual. CEO-driven mandate, no named AI structure.
tensionPositions.speedVsDepth: Initially Speed (full-tilt AI adoption), corrected to Depth (acknowledging need for human nuance).
tensionPositions.centralVsDistributed: Centralized decision, distributed impact. CEO made the call to go AI-first and to reverse.

openQuestions: What does the hybrid model look like now? How are AI and human agents coordinated in the corrected approach?
What organizational learning occurred from the reversal? Has Klarna created any formal AI governance since?
